Thank you for having me. This is actually, I
think, the first talk I've ever given to a
really purely HCI audience.

And as Michael was alluding to
as I was preparing this talk,

I was asking this question
of how did I end up here? Many of you I
recognize from CS155.

I teach the curriculum around
networking and security.

And if I go back to
five plus years ago, my research really focused
on these low level questions

of if we collect all of this
data about the internet, do we see things like biases in
the random number generator--

random numbers that
come out of dev urandom and does this tell us that
the way we use TLS is broken?

And is the way we standardize
network protocols calls broken? And this feels pretty
different than I think probably

a lot of the kind of topics
we talk about when we talk about society and about
people, and it didn't really

feel like there was necessarily
a lot of intersection between security and abuse and
hate and harassment online.

If you go back to the most
fundamental and stereotypical

parts of security, we have these
definitions around security, like the fact that we want
to provide confidentiality

and integrity, and availability
of the systems we're building. These core pillars of
what we think a system

has to have to be secure. And if you think, OK,
we're going to fix TLS.

We want to make sure TLS is
resilient from attackers,

from eavesdropping. You say, OK, this feels
fits very closely in with are we actually providing
confidentiality?

We're a community that loves
threat models, and to the point where we're almost a little
bit religious about having

to have a threat model
for really considering whether something is security.

And this is
something that if you want to publish a paper,
a top tier security venue,

you have to be able to really
articulate who is the attacker? And what are they
trying to achieve

when they break into a system? And we define security as
being resilient against this

defined attackers. We define these
safety mechanisms of what secure looks like,
and what are the capabilities

that this attacker has? And again, this doesn't feel
quite like hate and harassment.

I think we thought about
hate and harassment, interpersonal conflict
on the internet as there being this
clear attacker, which

is the nation state trying to
deploy ransomware or to achieve financial gain.

We'd to think about
attacks in these stages. We have this notion of
what's called the kill chain.

We have these
frameworks from Mitra, from other organizations
that say attacks happen

in these very specific
stages, and for the most part, this does hold. It's a little bit
reductive, but it's not

crazy to say really
attackers do go out and they do perform
Reconnaissance about the organization that
they're trying to attack,

or they try to look
at vulnerabilities more broadly across a large
swath of organizations

to see who's vulnerable. They figure out how can
they get initial access

into an organization? How do they crack
that outer shell? How do they get in?

How do they build persistence
within that organization so that they can carry
out attacks long term?

They figure out how
they can move laterally within that organization. How do they get from
that edge into where

the meaty, juicy details that
they want to steal or encrypt for ransomware are located
in the organization.

And they figure out how are they
going to extract and exfiltrate data?

And we like to think about
when we build defenses, this notion of defense in depth
of each one of these layers.

What are the defenses we
can build before people get to to the next stage?

And simultaneous
to this, I think, living in this ecosystem or
this set of abstractions,

I think there are a lot
of us in the community who are saying that we have this
massive hate and harassment

problem online. And I think in the
back of our heads, we have some notion of this
feels connected to security.

And I don't even know if
we could really quite put our finger on why
in the beginning that this felt a similar
problem space to us.

That there was this
harassment happening online. And in part it
could very well be

that in a lot of these
organizations like Google and YouTube and Facebook and
Twitter, actually the security

organizations were the ones
being tasked with preventing much of this abuse.

A lot of them fell
into these positions of being the ones trying
to protect against this,

even though we didn't
necessarily really know why,

per se. It was just this feeling
in the back of our head. And in 2022, there
was a group of us

that came together
and said, let's try to make a little bit
more sense of this. This was folks across the
whole security community,

both in industry and academia,
that of said like, well, how are these similar?

How are these different? Is hate and harassment
really a security problem? Is this a problem that
our community really

should be trying to address? Are we the best community to
try to address this problem?

Or is this really something that
we're really out of our depth on trying to go and
trying to make sense of?

And I will say the
research community was very resistant to
this in the beginning. They very much thought,
absolutely not.

I actually went back and
read the paper reviews I got, and it's easy to do
that in retrospect,

with your paper is
like is accepted. But we got these
scathing reviews.

And this was actually
like, this review did not get nicer after this. It kept getting worse
and worse and worse

of this person
saying like, how dare you try to measure online
hate and harassment?

This is a social science. This is not computer science. This is not security. Your paper should never
have been submitted here.

Why did you waste my time
submitting such a paper?

And I think it's because
really there was this mismatch. We were really focused
on attacks that

were financially motivated. We had this notion of this
is how ransomware works,

and this is how business email
compromise and phishing works, and this just didn't
fit into the mold.

And as I think as much as
we like to think that we as academic communities
are open to new ideas, in many cases we really aren't.

It doesn't have a threat model. There's no attacker. This is not security
was the notion.

And so we really looked
at this and said, what if we started to think
about online hate and harassment

actually as an attack? This is a major problem. We all think this is
something we have to address,

but really there is in many
of these cases an attack that targets someone.

There is maybe we don't
call them an adversary, but they're the aggressor. And there is a
target of this abuse,
and this can range quite widely.

The target could be
a single individual. It could be a group of people
that share a certain identity

or hold a certain
political belief, but there is someone in
almost all of these cases that has actually been targeted.

And there is a large swath,
but there isn't security too. There's large swaths
of different types

of people who are targeting
traditional cybersecurity attacks and same
thing for attackers.

There actually are
these models we can build of who is
perpetrating this abuse?

And again, this can range
from one person who's just making an abusive
comment on a one off on Reddit

or Twitter, all the way up to
coordinated mobs of thousands of people coming together
to essentially like

denial of service attack
a single individual. And we start going through
all of this literature, both--

a lot of it was actually in
more in the HCI community and saying like,
can we actually take

all of these different papers
and all of these different types of hate and
harassment that we see ranging from these
intimate partner violence

to online harassment and build
classes of attacks that we see?

And we came up with
these seven classes

of attacks or shapes
of attacks that we thought we could start
to abstract away. And I'm not necessarily
going to say

like, this is the gold
standard of classifications. I think if you asked
another 20 people to come up

with a set of
classifications, they might come up with a
slightly different one. But what we started
to see was we started

to see some similarities. If you start to look at things
like non-consensual sexual

deepfakes, where
you start to say, this is like an
impersonation type of attack.

If you look at revenge porn. There's a confidentiality
flavor you

can start to see in this
that is being violated. If you think about
toxic content.

This is something that's
forcing people off of platforms. It is forcing silence
in certain communities

or for certain identities. And we start to say,
look, we can map these to some of these concepts
that we have in the security

industry, and we can start to
see some parallels, actually,

to other types of
attacks or problems that traditionally we
have tried to solve

in the cybersecurity industry. And if you actually look
at something like spam.

Spam is actually interesting,
because spam is actually more of an abuse problem in many
ways than a security problem.

No system is being broken into. There is no buffer overflow. It is all-- you're
essentially all

of these spammers are
using email as intended according to the SMTP RFC.

They actually follow
it very, very closely because if you don't, you
get marked as a spammer now.

We've gotten very
persnickety about, do you implement this
protocol exactly right? So they follow
that to the letter,

but I think we've all said like
no spam is a security problem. Phishing we see as
a security problem.

Same thing. Phishing really is using
email just as intended at the protocol level.

We think about online censorship
as a security problem. Whether people have
access to certain content,

maybe this isn't that
crazy of a stretch, and this is the argument
that we made at the time.

And I think to Michael's
point, the few years after that became this kind
of question of OK,

if we actually think there
are all of these parallels, does this enable us to
approach these problems

from a different way? Are there different
techniques that we've used traditionally
in cybersecurity that we can use here?

What does this mean
for us as a community? And I think we've actually
seen a lot of success.

We're now at the point where if
you look at the call for papers from a venue like IEEE
security and privacy

or USENIX security, which
are of our top tier venues, they now all list online
hate and harassment,

actually, as within scope. It's something
that the community has come to say,
actually, yes, that

is something that is relevant. We are starting to
see the connections. I actually think we've been
in some ways quite successful

as something that went
from over our dead bodies. We don't want that. That's not even
computer science.

To being something
that is being solicited in many of these communities.

I actually think
we overestimate. Sorry. No.

This sentence actually went
back to the paper last night, and we said, there are
all these similarities,

but there are some
differences too. In security, we like to
think about cost centers

and how we can break at friction
within these attack chains.

Interesting Catherine wrote
a paper two years later, which said the
most effective way,

really at addressing

Stefan Savage had written

about 30 years ago in
the security community, and run one, actually
run a MacArthur for at the time of
saying, stop just

looking at all of
these technical pieces. Go look at the money flows. It turns out that actually the

you can't use these
hosting providers or you can't use these
domain registrars,

played out pretty

bulletproof hosting providers.

These sites, for the most

and sites hosting child
sexual abuse material moved.

The exact same pattern came out
that the most effective thing to do is if you were able
to get ads off of a site.

And if you were able
to get them off, thrown off like a
donation provider like PayPal, that
was actually what was effective at having
some of these hate sites

disappear, so I actually
think we saw ourselves short a little bit.

And we came into this originally

about another issue that
isn't quite security, which is misinformation

like we felt like there
was these connections between security

of the world against them. But there, again,
is an attacker, and there is a target
in most of these cases.

Now, does this get really

to being misinformation,
which is just more organically repeated? Yes, absolutely.

But it doesn't mean that there
wasn't an original intent when the piece of propaganda

story was originally released.

And actually, Hutch,

this is actually the
kill chain that Meta has for going
after I/O campaigns

on the platform at
the time, and it looks nearly identical
to actually the kill

chains we traditionally
used in cybersecurity. It turned out if you

for example, in Russia, many of

carry out cybersecurity,
traditional cybersecurity attacks. They get repurposed, but it's
the same military units that

are carrying out both,
and the attackers are of using the same techniques. We've also seen the merging of
all of these things together.

Now, if you get
hit by ransomware, we'll also see things like

in making those decisions also

or have disinformation

We see them targeting
specific individuals online.

We see actually like
increasingly more crossover,

even within gang activity
between these traditional cybersecurity attacks

about governments,

attack at the same time, your personal photos
of your family

by different threat groups.

And so there's all
these similarities if all of these

What can we use from

And take this from

So the first paper
I want to talk about is one that Catherine
led, that looked

at how do we help
journalists essentially use social media effectively?

Now, if you talk to a lot of
journalists, especially folks from marginalized
identities, a lot of them

receive are just

hateful, vitriolic messages. It's not like, hey, we have
a couple of percentages.

It's the majority of messages
they receive on Twitter. In some cases, it's the

that they receive
are hateful messages. So if that is the
ecosystem that they operate

in-- and at the same
time, like social media is actually really critical
to these journalists.

It's how they engage
with their communities. It's how they
publish their work.

In many ways, they
actually they want to know about this criticism. They don't want to
operate in a vacuum.

There's these journalistic
norms that you should be as a generalist,
going and interacting

with your readership and
understanding their views. And so we ended up having
this interesting world where

journalists had this
need to use social media, that it was critical
to their profession.

And at the same
time, the majority of everything they receive is
hateful messages, so you can't just say, hey, don't use social
media, don't use Twitter,

don't use email. And we saw this I
think these two halves.

There's this what
we ended up calling utility and reciprocation,
which actually pulled

from the norms of the
journalistic community and this was a need. They had this need to
continue to reciprocate

with their audience. They also had the need that
they had to protect themselves against these attacks.

And you might be saying

that already did this? We have Block Party

these actually weren't working. There was a couple
of reasons why. One was just the total volume
of the number of accounts

that they were seeing
this content from. Going after this user by user
was not a particularly fruitful

approach. But more fundamentally, this
whole notion of blocking things

was actually a problem. And I think when
we think of saying, OK, we're just going to block
someone on Twitter, maybe

that seems fine. But in many ways, to many
of these journalists, this was actually
enabling the attackers. It was telling the
attackers they won.

It was telling
attackers that they didn't want to hear from them. And newsrooms came out
and said, actually, we

don't want you blocking people. We don't want it to

different communities,

so you can't use these
tools because it's visible who you blocked. So we're in this world where
the tools don't work right.

They don't really meet needs. They can't be deployed given
the journalistic norms.

And at the same time,
they've effectively made much of the social

And as we went through

axes that we had to think about.

One was just is it toxic or not? But there's this other axis of
whether it was relevant or not?

And this sounds-- it
sounds so obvious now,

It's not really

If someone is really upset

There's other stuff where

Not that they did not want
